Comment: Bernier might be able to speak to those who value tax reduction above all else -- but he might have trouble with voters who have a facility for basic arithmetic.

Balancing the budget in two years by cutting taxes is quite a stretch.  He freely admits that he hasn't done the math, and probably a good thing, too.

I don't dispute that targeted tax cuts can sometimes increase revenue by stimulating the economy.   But Bernier's plan smacks of Reagan's voodoo economics.  While overall growth was rather good in the Reagan years, he tripled the federal debt.

Deficit spending is not always a bad thing.  But cutting taxes and balancing the budget sounds oxymoronic to me, and Mr Bernier will have to provide a more detailed plan to  have any credibility whatsoever on that claim.

Comment: Premier Clark clearly wants another election immediately & she wants to somehow force the Lieutenant Governor (LG) to call it without herself taking political responsibility for advising the LG to take this course of action.  This is an abuse of a First Minister's role & duty in these circumstances.

 It's the constitutional duty under the parliamentary system for a First Minister, on losing a Vote of Confidence, to advise the Queen's Representative whether to 
(a) ask the Leader of the Opposition if he/she can form a Government that will have the confidence of the House,  or 
(b) call an election.  
Except in highly unusual circumstances (not including those currently in BC), option (b) does not apply where the Government loses a Vote of Confidence at the first opportunity for such a vote after a General Election.

It's simply wrong for Clark to play these games by trying to shift her responsibility as a defeated Premier onto the shoulders of the LG .

Comment: We've seen very clearly at both the state and the national level that our current system based on multiple for-profit insurance companies cannot deliver affordable care to all individuals. We are the only wealthy nation that does not have a national health system with a national patient pool, and that is why our health care system is so inferior to other countries.

However, there has been so much misinformation about single-payer systems (for example, many people don't realize that single payer systems give them much more freedom and choice than our current system) that it isn't politically possible to change all at once. I would like to see a system where Medicare and Medicaid (and perhaps other government plans) are combined into one single plan, and then households and businesses are allowed to purchase into that plan. A plan that large would spread risk over more patients and would also have bargaining power to drive down costs.

Comment: Initially, I was very sceptical of Edmonton's deal with Katz to get the new arena done. Katz's ham-handed, arrogant negotiating was particularly revolting. 

Now that the new arena is up and operating I accept that the deal is going to be a winner for Edmonton as much as it is a winner for Katz. The 'Ice District' redevelopment is truly spectacular and will spur more and more redevelopment in ever-widening circles in forthcoming years. In 50 years the former wasteland of downtown Edmonton will be completely transformed.

Already it is easy to see a new vibrancy in Edmonton's inner city. This was already beginning pre-Rogers but is now accelerating. In a perverse way the recent U-Haul terrorist incident gave proof to this. Previously, Jasper Ave after midnight was barren and unpopulated. Not so now.

I must also admit that the new arena is really a rather spiffy joint for watching hockey.

Comment: The Sullivan Arena is a relic of an era in which sports stadiums were sited effectively all by themselves, under the assumption that people would get their entertainment be driving their cars from home through horrendous traffic to get there, staying for the event and the captive-audience overpriced concessions, driving their cars home through horrendous traffic afterward, and then being happy with the experience.

Sports arenas nowadays—at least the better, more successful ones—have been built in areas that are surrounded by bars and restaurants and other commercial establishments (and no, the strip club across the street from the Sullivan Arena doesn't count!), andthat are accessible via means other than one or two people in a car (such as mass transit or walking), and that provide a fuller entertainment experience than simply sitting in a big cave to watch an event.

The Sullivan Arena is a dinosaur (and an ugly one, at that), and it's time to find a way to put it out of its misery.

Comment: Henry Ford famously hired a private army headed by an ex Naval officer to run it.  They attacked workers at off site organizing points, caused riots at pro-union demos, "visited" workers at their homes.  They were the original "goons". 

In recent years Walmart, McDonalds, Nissan, Toyota, Honda and a host of other corporations, small and large have run (and continue to run) anti-union campaigns in the workplace.  Private security companies, from Pinkerton's on, have formed the core of a transnational union busting industry that has grown ever more sophisticated since the head breaking days of the 19th century. During the height of pre-war labour radicalism in Ontario, the populist premier, Mitchell Hepburn, used public money to hire 400 goons known as "Hepburn's Hussars" to break the UAW's organizing in Oshawa.  

 It was the courts in Canada, not the government, that decided, amongst other things, that the employer has numerous unfair advantages in countering union organizing drives.

Comment: In most fields, women don't receive their fair share, i.e. they're 30% of the applications and "win" 20% of the time,  or in the case of chairs they're 30% of scientists but they receive a smaller proportion. This is what it is about.

 The problem with the merit-based system is that there seems to be many biases against women (and against younger scientists and minorities). For example, women are less likely to be invited as guest speakers even when they represent 50% of the research community. Their resumes end up being less padded and they then don't get the chairs positions.  Furthermore, men tend to be more emphatic when describing their achievements, and women tend to be judged more harshly by reviewers including by women. This is all backed up by evidence, so we have to realize that particular efforts need to be made to address the situation, to get to the point of having a real objective merit-based system..

The Cabinet is a different situation and I'm all out of characters.

Comment: I'm going by the article.  I'll definitely consider your point of view but it stands as an alternative point of view, not gospel.  As far as 'political failure' my opinion that America makes horrible political choices is not based on this single episode.  I will concede that if your assertions prove correct, that Houston falls outside the pattern.  
The critique against flood planning in the USA isn't that dikes, flood plains aren't built and that water management does not take place.  It's that such projects do not take account of disasters sufficiently.  There is also a school of thought that the capitalist system as it exists in the USA relies on disasters as a form of capital opportunity.  It's a tenuous thesis, but the evidence based on American history is extensive and documented in a book called 'Shock Doctrine'.  I think the original post comparing the Mexican Wall to the seawall not built in Houston is meet to where America stands today. I stand by everything I have posted.

Comment: In the last 45 days, the Toronto market has shifted in a completely different way compared to the Vancouver market after the introduction of the tax there. It's silly to make projections for Toronto based on Vancouver, because the experiences so far have been so different and because the causes are different. 

Listings in Toronto have surged and sales have plummeted. In Vancouver, new listings actually DECREASED following the introduction of the tax. 

Furthermore, the Toronto tax is more robust, has fewer exemptions and is tied to Teranet rather than relying on self-reporting like the Vancouver tax. 

But more importantly, what we are seeing in Toronto is a reaction in part to the Home Capital Group situation and the attendant increased borrowing costs/unavailability of credit for the riskiest borrowers in Toronto.

Comment: There are two core themes to the column:
1) Trump is inept
2) The terms "fake news" is being broadened to mean things that it probably should not.

I have my own opinions on 1) that clearly some others disagree with, but frankly I didn't see anything too controversial on 2).

What I think I read was that fake news is not:
i)   opinion pieces (such as Tabatha Southey's columns, unless they knowingly present untruths as fact)
ii)  bad news
iii) news the reader doesn't agree with, but is factually correct
iv) information that the writer presents as uncertain
v)  news in a rapidly emerging story, where the "facts" are presented as "what we think we know so far", and updated as more information comes in.

Fake news is:
vi) knowingly presenting information as fact when it is not
vii) presenting guesswork as fact. 

On Twitter and at the news conference, Trump clearly classified "news" in categories i-v as fake to devalue it. This is a problem - with Trump or anybody else. Simple, and obvious

Comment: Actually, in the current context, the "father of all deficits" is one Stephen Harper.
.
When he came into office Canada was running a strong structural surplus, and had been doing so for the golden decade under Paul Martin.
.
The Harper government cut the GST.  What a terrible mistake.
.
That decision has added roughly $160 Billion to the accumulated public debt, it ended Canada's structural surplus, it led to the running-down of Canada's public sector plant and infrastructure (i.e., the equivalent of thinking you are saving money by never fixing the roof) and put the budget into deficit for the entirety of Harper's term of office.
.
The economy was, in fact, much healthier overall when Canada had both higher spending and higher taxes under Paul Martin.
.
 Tax cuts are sometimes a very, very bad idea.
.
The financial damage done to Canada during the Harper decade will not be fixed for a  long time.

Comment: If you read the whole story and place the quote in context, you will find out that the judge said that person who is unconscious or who is conscious but so intoxicated she doesn't know what she was doing cannot consent, but a person who is drunk but still in touch with reality can consent. That is an entirely correct statement of the law.

In the case in question, the judge was given two snapshots. At one point in time, the complainant was clearly intoxicated but conscious, walking, arguing with her friends, and calling a cab. Eleven minutes later, she was found unconscious with most of her clothes off. Judge Lenehan found, quite reasonably, that at the earlier time the complainant was capable of consent but at the later time she was not. The reference to "a drunk can consent" applied to the complainant's state at the earlier time, not the later one.

Comment: Make health care a public service--as it is, in fact--no more private care anywhere.
Plan health care needs for 5-10 year spans, anticipating changing needs in the population.
Identify the number, type, & service area, of health care providers that will be required to meet those needs.
Recruit students only to meet those needs, which may not be their personal preference; support their education & training. 
Ensure that medical training graduates those numbers and types; set standards for that training & ensure that they're met.
Hire graduates to work in the type of service, in the geographic area, & the health sector needed. Employ them in egalitarian health teams of professionals, to provide a full spectrum of care. Pay for their physical locations, & other administrative expenses, as for other public servants. Same benefits, same vacations, etc.
Establish performance standards, monitor performance, reward and punish as appropriate.
Stop us being held hostage by these practitioners.

Comment: I'm afraid that doesn't address the budgeting issue at all. Imagine the US military spends equal amounts on Viagra and transgenderification. The former treatment might cover (say) 10,000 soldiers, and most likely ones that are senior officers and such. The latter treatment however might cover 100 soldiers, and they're likely to be younger and less experienced soldiers.

It's easy to see which is the more efficient use of funds in dealing with soldiers' medical concerns. One simple pill keeps thousands of soldiers happy, whereas a very expensive medical procedure keeps a relative few happy. No brainer for the military.

Comment: That's fundamentally correct, but it's not crazy. In general, it's how all currency is created and sustained. Someone puts a lot of time and energy into something, say digging for gold. It's really hard to find gold, so when its unearthed its worth a lot. Bingo, you just created wealth. 

Crypto-currency is based on the same concept. A task requiring a lot of time and energy is what creates the currency. But no further steps are involved. Paper currency is based indirectly on something, like gold. The intermediaries in that indirect relationship are banks and governments. Crypto-currency is based on itself. It's not a paper representation of wealth that's offered by a bank or government, and which can be manipulated in infinite ways. Crypto-currency is like doing your transactions by exchanging gold with another willing party. Banks and governments are not intermediaries, and don't profit from it.

Comment: In broadcasting, the high highfalutin word "dis-intermediation" has been used to describe the process whereby companies using new technologies can reach consumers directly with their advertising and promotions without having to go through broadcasters who traditionally controlled access to large audiences which they brought  together to watch their programs.  Now, similarly, Trump has dis-intermediated the traditional media to reach the public directly, through Twitter, with his thoughts, comments and policy positions. The public gets to hear Trump without the traditional media first having the opportunity to decide on what to pass on to the public, and how to frame what they do pass on.  In a very real sense, Trump has expanded the diversity of political voices, which is a critical component of a democracy.

Comment: Wrong.  The Feds are on the right track.  You need to consider Portugal: 15 years ago they had a serious drug problem.  So they legalized all drugs and moved money from police to health care.  Today, they have a much fewer people using drugs.  Those with addictions have quick access to addiction reduction care.  They have a lot fewer in jail eating up tax dollars, and fewer drug criminals causing violence.  AIDS went from epidemic worst in Europe, to one of the lowest in Europe.  

Prohibition has not worked.  And now the traffickers can sneak in tiny quantities of fentanyl and carfentanil that the border services have no hope in stopping.  Prohibition is part of the problem!  We ought to be doing what Portugal did and moving those resources to treatment (and maybe jailing doctors for prescribing oxy, the real nub of the epidemic)

Comment: I read your comment carefully.  Your logic is faulty.
.
The OP's point is that the argument is not binary.  They did not suggest that the relative ratios of influences (nature / nurture) are the greatest issue but the relative differences between men and women that are at issue.   The quote used is "the size of these negative emotion sex differences is not very large.. ..accounting for less than 10% of the variance".  That is, the difference between men and women is small.
.
Your tangent claims that whatever the ratio of influences between nature/nurture that the outcomes of peoples desires is the only measure to determine the makeup of a workplace.  This assumes that the "nurture" part of the equation is exactly the same for both men and women.  That is a fault assumption.  
.
So to answer your question ... yes, sometimes a more gender equal workplace should be forced.  Google is probably more right than wrong in this.  
.
That said, they were 100% wrong to fire Damore.

Comment: Generally a fair article, but it's disappointing that it repeats on the common lies from SB 91 supporters: that it simply replicates measures other states have successfully implemented. The truth is that NONE of the other reform success stories cited by Pew did anything close to SB 91 in scale or scope. In Texas, for instance, a person who steals a car is looking at 6 to 24 months in prison for a first offense. Post SB 91, that person in Alaska couldn't get a day of jail time.

The only state that did anything comparable to Alaska was California -- and that effort is pretty universally considered almost as big a failure as SB 91.

Comment: Nonsense.  In a Defined Benefits Plan when you die, maybe at an early age, all your contributions, your employer's contributions and any investment income stays with the plan.  Your spouse if you have one may get a portion of your pension when she is of retirement age  but your estate gets nothing!  
In a Defined Benefits Plan, RRSP,  all the money in the Plan belongs to you and when you die it can be rolled over tax free to your spouse or goes to your estate- and maybe dependent children, after tax..  
 DB plans pay more pension because the  money paid in by those that die early  benefits the long livers.   So if you have a DB plan and worry about your spouse if you die before them you better have back up

Comment: The proposal to increase the corporate income tax is a welcome development and shows real progress in Salem.

I've been harshly critical of Legislators for their single-minded focus on the gross receipts tax and was just about giving up hope that anything would be accomplished this session. This new development shows a pragmatism that has been missing. It has business support and support from Republican legislators.

The next tax to reform is the personal income tax, where the highest income people pay practically the same top tax rate as someone making less than $20,000 per year.

With low and middle incomes in a structural stagnation, and high incomes rising, it makes sense to establish higher personal income tax rates for the top 1% of earners. They can afford it, while lower income people cannot afford any new tax, including higher prices from a gross receipts tax.

Comment: .

I took the survey.

It was simple, easy to understand and fill out.

It hardly touched on the issue of the ballot - FPTP, Preferred/Ranked Ballot or Proportional Representation.

It read to me as if it was designed to determine general priorities of survey respondents rather than their ballot preferences.

All this criticism from the opposition is just a lot of hot air.

The CPC wants FPTP because they will never be able to pull in the support of a majority of voters with a ranked ballot or PR and will likely see their seat share shrink.

The NDP wants PR because it will likely increase their seat share.

The Liberals want ranked ballot because, where they are not first choice, they will always be second choice and thus gain seats.

None of the options are perfect.

Which is the least imperfect?

Comment: So is my son. He should study hard so that he excels academically, make connections with his professors, take opportunities to hone his research and communication skills (verbal and written), seek out experiential learning opportunities (e.g. co-op, internship, lab/research assistant, TA), join clubs - both academic and social, attend conferences and symposiums, and actively network while rounding out his education in the arts/humanities/social sciences. If possible he should also consider studying abroad. Basically the same things he should do regardless of career focus. Certainly he needs to stand out academically, but there is more to being successful in a career than knowledge and technical expertise in one's field. It's just as much about who you know and what connections you can make. In order network he needs to be articulate and broadly educated in areas outside his field so that he can converse intelligently on a variety of topics. It's all about being able to market yourself.

Comment: I've been an on-again, off-again member of the K of C since college, some 40 years ago. (Truth be told, more off than on.) I think of the organization in a couple of ways. On the local level, most of the Knights I know are decent guys, middle-to-right Catholics not terribly interested in politics who like getting together to do good things for the community and, of course, drink beer. Harmless enough and not much different from Rotarians or Elks.

But on the national and international level, the K of C is a monster. Their influence on bishops is staggering. Follow the money in any diocese and it likely won't be long until you find a K of C connection. That's not about service alone but also about power, and Carl Anderson -- who far from being a "former" political operative is still very much engaged in promoting GOP causes -- is not shy about wielding it. That's what we should be concerned about.

Comment: A Defined Contribution plan only costs less if the contribution rates are less.  If the contribution rates are the same then the costs are similar.

BUT...

A defined benefit pension has much larger risks and liabilities for a company.  While they can take a "contribution holiday" when times are good (in fact the law almost requires it), they sometimes get hit with a requirement to pump extra funds into the fund when times are bad.  This tends to hit companies when they are least able to afford it.

For members of the pension plans, a DC fund and DB fund will pay out EXACTLY the same amount if the contributions are the same and the returns are the same.  The only time they differ is if one or other are different, which is often the case.  A large part of the "advantage" of a Defined Benefit fund comes from comparing a DB plan with 15 to 20% contribution rates to a DC plan with 5 to 10% contribution rates.

Comment: It's worth pointing out that the survey in the Black Experience Project didn't get a random sample of Black Canadians, and it also didn't collect any numbers to compare the responses to. That is, the BEP's report doesn't tell us how Canadians of other ethnicities report their experience of microaggressions; nor does it tell us how Black Canadians' answers to the questions have changed over time.

So the Black Experience Project can collect some interesting qualitative data and highlight perceived problems. In particular, the interview responses can give us a glimpse of *how* racism is felt by Black people to work.

But the BEP can't give us a very clear picture of how widespread racism is, given both the lack of representativeness and the lack of any comparison between groups or over time.

Comment: Jesus never mentioned hell. That word was inserted by St. Jerome when he wrote the Vulgate. We have no words of Mary concerning hell in the Gospels. And she left no writings. As for the saints, they are welcome to their opinions, but none of them knew for certain either. Holiness does not make someone infallible or all-knowing. 
I don't know whether or not their is a heaven or hell. I certainly hope there is an Afterlife of some kind, preferably some sort of union with God. I'd love to think it's the kind where we'd really meet our loved ones again, or get to meet famous people who died before us--I have a lot of questions for some people-- but we really have no way of knowing for sure at all. 
I try to live following what Jesus said--to love God and to love my neighbor. I'm not always very good at it, but I do try. As for heaven, I'll leave that in God's hands. The only thing we have for sure is this life, this NOW. If we are to find God, THIS is where God is found.

So like many other self employed people no work no pay, no vacation pay not even the mandatory 2 weeks and 9 days of statutory pay that the rest of the work force gets as manditory the they punch their first time clock . The doctors pay both their cpp and ei and the employer portion. Doctors who run a small business, I.e. Pay rent, lease printers, buy paper, pens in short office supplies - phone bills and pay all the hst but when they bill OHIP their key income source they cannot bill HST for the service rendered therefore cannot claim an hst refund for the office. Comment: Years ago I read an article, which proposed that making claims about empathy is a kind of presumption.(Unfortunately I can't remember the author.  Austin Clarke perhaps? Comment: It's only "cool" to be sarcastic if you know what you're talking about.  Clearly you don't.

I "rescued" my last cat as a tiny kitten from Sand Pt. in November of 2004.  He lived 12 years safe, happy and well-cared for in my home as an indoor-only cat until he succumbed to cancer in October 2016.  I kept him going as long as I could until he could no longer stand or eat.  I held him in my arms, and he hid his face in the crook of my arm (as he'd always done when he needed to feel secure) as the vet gave him his last shot. Comment: Apparently the author of this column did not read this article which appeared on BBC news (Dec 2, 2016) and many other news sites:  "Four Major Cities Move to Ban Diesel Vehicles by 2025". 

"The leaders of four major global cities say they will stop the use of all diesel-powered cars and trucks by the middle of the next decade.

The mayors of Paris, Mexico City, Madrid and Athens say they are implementing the ban to improve air quality. ....

Diesel engines contribute to the problem in two key ways - through the production of particulate matter (PM) and nitrogen oxides (NOx). Very fine soot PM can penetrate the lungs and can contribute to cardiovascular illness and death.

Nitrogen oxides can increase ground level ozone and this can exacerbate breathing difficulties, even for people without a history of respiratory problems."

(Most cars burn gasoline and NOT diesel.  Most cars have multiple pollution controls to keep from polluting the air: catalytic converters, EGRs, etc. etc.)

Comment: Good grief, yourself.  Yes, CO2 is a greenhouse gas, but  a relatively incidental one.  The primary greenhouse gas is water vapor, but even that isn't the primary cause of climate change.  The sun is.  Our orbit is constantly changing in shape, and our distance from the sun constantly changes; the sunspot activity varies and constantly changes the amount of solar radiation we receive; and the tilt of the earth's axis constantly changes, and even "flips" the positive and negative poles over time.  When we're closer to the sun, it warms, and when we're further away, we have ice ages.  And there's nothing we can do about it but adapt to the changes as they happen.

Comment: I can see the problem.  It's called boredom.

Due to flight schedules, pilots are expected to wait around for hours at a time in airports until their next flight.  Airports are notoriously uncomfortable places to wait around, with chairs designed to be uncomfortable to sleep in, the lights are always on, constant announcements and your lucky just to find a television playing something other than flight schedules with audio enabled.

Leave the airport and you have to queue up for security searches on your way back in, and if it is an international flight you will have to clear customs in both directions which also takes time and a long time in queue.

For these pilots, a way to kill the time is to hit one of the ubiquitous bars near the gate.  One drink leads to another, which leads to another, as they kill hour after hour waiting around.  Sure they could eat, and they probably do, but in a 6 hour layover there's only so many meals you can have. Give them a place to nap.

Comment: Sorry for replying twice, but after writing the last bit, there is a far-more-important related point here. It isn't search engines, it's social media networks. On Twitter and Facebook people tend to connect to like-minded people, and in aggregate these tightly-knit 'tribal' sub-networks end up growing huge. And this makes it very easy for fake news to go viral, because you just put a spurious claim that supports your own side into the piece of the network, and it generates large amounts of outrage very quickly, getting shared with hundreds of thousands of people. Somewhere buried in the comments under it there might be "Actually, this is completely fabricated, if you check out the source," but few people pay much attention to that. Too hard to go against the feeling that 'This article was Liked by 100,000 people who are sensible like me, so it must be accurate.'

And Wente is right, it happens in left-wing networks just as much as pro-Trump networks.

Comment: Somerset lies: a bump-fire stock will not allow a semi-automatic AR15 style rifle to fire at the same rate as a fully-automatic machine gun. It will approximate the rate of fire of an automatic rifle. 

If you need to know the difference:
A bump fire stock increases the rate of fire of a semi-automatic rifle to about 400 rounds per minute.  
A C8 automatic rifle like our Canadian Infantry uses have a cyclic rate of 750 to 950 rounds per minute. 
What remains unspoken in the discussion is that both of the above rates are limited by how the cartridges are fed into the gun: a 30-round magazine, which is standard capacity on an AR15, would be empty in seconds and require replacement. A C8 operates so on a 100-round drum or is fed by a disintegrating belt.
The lightest machine guns, like the M249 Squad Automatic Weapon, are substantially heavier than an infantry weapon. They have rates of fire of 800 rounds per minute, while heavy (typically mounted) machine guns have a lower rate of fire.

From an investment perspective, the author avoids a tax discussion, and this is important.  He noted "it could earn her roughly $250,000 a year, or more than $20,000 a month... rented...apartment for around $8,000 a month. "

Earning 20k per month that is taxed, assuming eligible dividends, would net 14k or 160k per year.  If you own a 5mm home, then presumably you have some income to cover that 60k per year maintenance and lifestyle spending. Perhaps 250k or so.   Downgrading in size to a 8k/mo apartment - likely 1/3 or less the sq ft of the home - is a big change.  Likely no stay overs for the grandkids anymore, etc. Also, at disposition, cap gains on home are tax free vs. 30+pc for investments. So home appreciation at 3% equates to ~5-6% earned on investments.  Financially, these don't seem far apart..it's about lifestyle.

Comment: Billy Ray Powers:  I worked 20 years on a Sheriff's Dept., in the lower 48 before moving to Alaska. First, the number of traffic citations issued per mo.  Second, he graphed the number of accidents per mo.  Third, and last he graphed the number of injury/fatality accidents per mo.  After 20 years of doing this, the results were extremely telling.  EVERY single time that traffic citations went up, you saw where accidents/injury accidents/fatalities went down.  This happened EVERY single time for over 20 years.  Yes, profits go up when more citations are written but to ignore traffic enforcement for ANY reason would be a travesty and would result in citizens being injured and killed along with thousands upon thousands of dollars of property damage.  Citizens may hate traffic​ enforcement but, , , IT IS NEEDED!!!

Comment: “Any sign should be low key. Something you don’t even see.”

In regards to individual donors, it's a nice unobtrusive acknowledgement of their contributions, something for the passerby to stumble upon.

In regards to organizations and businesses, branding is most effective when it's embedded into the everyday seemlessly. If we "discover" that a park is sponsored by X group, we implicitly garner more positive feelings towards X group.

I'm more wary of things that are low-key, because subtlety is the most powerful tool there is in rooting and manipulating behaviors and emotions in people.

Comment: I wish there was a way to search comments.

I don't know if a comment states the efficiencies of gas, diesel and stations power plants. Gas engines are about 25% to 30% efficient, meaning only 1/4 of the energy going into the engines, pushes the car along, 3/4 goes out the tail pipe as heat. Diesels run 30% to 35% efficient, hence they can deliver better mileage. Electric motors run about 95% efficient.

Stationary power plants can optimized for energy and emissions output. Cars and trucks run optimally for a narrow range of speed and load, most of the time they run less than their possible efficiency. Old and primitive thermal power plants probably were about 20% to 25% efficient. Today they will push 40% efficient, maybe 50%. The very very very large marine diesels can run close to 50% when utilizing all the exhaust gas energy recovery systems available.

Electric motors deliver energy more efficiently than internal combustion engines.

Comment: Those arguing for and against universal basic income tend to base their respective positions on sweeping assumptions about human nature. Those against it, for example, often argue that the scheme will sap people of their will to work and desire to better themselves, which rests on the supposition that money alone drives an individual to be productive. Those for it tend to exaggerate the extent to which providing basic material comforts alone result in happy citizens and a healthy society, an assumption that is belied by the poor socio-economic outcomes among current income assistance recipients in Canada.

Instead of debating human nature, a generally fruitless endeavour, we should simply test the idea in the real world to see if it works.  The Ontario government is right to pilot UBI, but the whole enterprise is dependent on the results being measured with brutal honesty and objectivity. If it doesn't work, we have to acknowledge it.

Comment: "Reverse discrimination" IS a fallacy.  It doesn't exist and presupposes only one type of discrimination.  Only discrimination exists, either positive or negative.  When you only hire a man, you positively discriminate for men, and against women.  When you only hire a woman it's the opposite.  It's just good old discrimination, plain and simple, with some people believing it's justifiable, and others no.  Discrimination has always been justified by its supporters, in whatever context.     

On a personal note, I find the whole use of the word "privilege" misguided.  Like many others, I was taught that privilege is earned.  While I fully understand the argument that some people are born with more advantage than others, I find that the use of the word "privilege" weakens the argument and preaches to the converted.

Comment: Breaking down a carcass it truly a beautiful thing! Practicing the art of proper cuts with respect to the grain, marbling, connective tissues and bones can be a fulfilling experience. Everyone who cooks should at least buy a whole quarter and practice butchering it and putting it up in the freezer as well as preserve it by smoking, dehydrating, salting and pickling. Hacksaw the bones for stock and marrow. Get acquainted with with the anatomy of this nutritious protein while there is still time. After the Carrs, Fred Meyers and Costcos have been looted, you won't be able to buy veggie medlies or tofu. Chances are all the farms and truck gardens will be ravaged and berries only grow in summer.

Comment: My oldest daughter is applying to uni and I’m very worried that, compared to when I graduated in 1982, education has become much narrower and Orwellian. Words have become twisted:  killing babies in the womb is called ‘choice’ or ‘reproductive health’, any objective critique of sexual behaviour with reference to biology, psychiatry and ethics is called ‘homophobia’, and invitations to rational debate are dismissed as ‘bigotry’.
Mainstream Catholic colleges, like BC, NDame, and G’town, are Catholic in name only—they’re Catholic in the same way that Harvard is Congregationalist.   If these colleges really wanted to be a voice of clarity  in the wilderness, they would become an oasis of truth in a world where words have lost meaning and free speech is no longer even remembered.

Comment: Zay, I think the characterization 'higher risk' is purely based on the fact that this is an 100% equity product, not because covered calls are used.

Covered calls work the best in a generally flat to declining market.

Comment: One of the things that those of us who managed to get beyond Econ 101 understand is the difference between elastic and inelastic markets. The markets for basic foodstuffs and labour are both inelastic, which means that simple supply/demand does not work well. 

The other thing some of us understand is that some decisions are necessarily collective, not individual. The most obvious example is that there is no particular reason to prefer the left or the right side of the road; however, we must all drive on the same side. You do not have an individual right to choose which side of the road to drive on. Unionisation is another one of those necessarily collective decisions. Either all the workers in a particular workplace need to join the union, or none. "Right to work" which forbids mandatory union membership, is effectively a ban on unions, a gross violation of freedom of association, and economically unwise besides. It's the main reason why US wages are not keeping up.

Comment: No electoral system is perfect. But PR has a far worse track record than FPTP over the last century. How did Hitler rise to power in 1933: PR system. Why can't Israel fend off its own radical minority elements and move closer to real peace with its neighbours: nearly pure PR in the Knesset. Where are the right wing parties making the biggest inroads in Europe? The PR systems, including, most likely, the Netherlands soon. Italy has had over 60 governments since WWII: PR. The European PIIGS which all got into severe economic crisis over the last decade: ALL PR. Russia: PR with high threshold locks Putinesque parties in the Duma. Wonder what keeps Erdogan in power in Turkey: a PR system with a high threshold. I've studied electoral systems for years, and all the supposed benefits of PR overlook the empirical reality of PR's institutional effects on politics. For a federal Canada, it would be a disaster.

Comment: I don't think you appreciate the amount of taxpayer money that went into building that site, over $80 million was spent building a very well-engineered casting basin. To simply fill it in and pave it over is a tremendous waste of money that we, the taxpayer, have already spent on the site. And the report indicates that vessel haul out, repair, and/or scrapping is an actual feasible use of the site. Yes, money would have to be spent, just like when any other business moves to a new location. The fact remains that if a business moved to the site, it would be saving about $80 million on a pre-built basin. That's hardly cost prohibitive, that's a steal. 

All I'm saying is it's a waste to fill it in, and there are businesses and other uses that could be found for that site. Besides, while car exports are great and all, the amount of jobs generated per square foot of land used is pretty pathetic, compared to manufacturing or other marine dependent businesses.

Comment: Mr Lieberman. I enjoyed reading your article titled "Freestyle traveling" in the RG today. 
My wife and I did a house exchange through <http://homelink.org> in 8/2001 with a family from Oxford, England. At the time our daughter, Jenny,  was 15 and our son, Michael,  was 18.  My wife TJ, who is a New Zealander,  and I wanted to give them an overseas experience to instill the 'travel bug' in their minds. We then discovered 'Homelink' by an internet travel search and found a number of interesting opportunities in England. After submitting photos of our house, we received a response from Shelley and Ian Salisbury of Oxford. Within a few weeks, and 2 emails, we had settled on a mutually agreeable 3 week exchange. On the agreed date, we flew to Oxford, picked up their car at the airport and drove to their home. Our 1st dinner  was already prepared. We had a great time touring England and even Paris in 3 weeks. I only write to urge you to mention "homelink" in any future article. Dave Russell

Comment: The dams are not being overtopped at this point.  They're releasing a controlled amount through the gates and an additional amount is now going over the spillways. Agree that actual overtopping or failure of either one would do untold additional damage from the west side of Houston through downtown.

Comment: As we're so often reminded, the climate accord is voluntary. The US has not committed to any funding in its nationally determined contribution, only carbon targets. The funding the US has donated to the Green Climate Fund is voluntary and is not even mentioned in our NDC. Trump has already stopped contributing to the GCF and could have done so without withdrawing from the accord.

So economically, we can do whatever we'd like as long as we meet our self-declared CO2 targets. In the country's better days, this would be seen as a grand challenge to develop an economy based around renewables, just like the challenge to reach the moon. Now all we can do is complain that it's going to cost us a few thousand coal jobs. And the problem with rallying around coal is that renewables are approaching grid parity whether you ignore them or not. The price of solar is falling exponentially; the market is growing - we can be the ones making the panels, or the ones buying them from China. Your choice.

Comment: @SnarkyBones
Re: "but you can if you're at a gun show or are on the internet"

All gun shows are heavily monitored by the BATF and local police and with the exception of a few individuals walking around with a hand made sign advertising a personal firearm for sale, all of the sellers are licensed gun dealers (FFL's) that are required to run a background check on all sales. Guns can be purchased over the Internet but to be legal they have to go through an FFL at the buyer's end or at the seller's end.

Re: "You can't have grenades"

Yes you can. Civilians can and do own grenades under the provisions of the 1934 National Firearms Act (NFA) and you never hear about any of them being used in a crime. They are classified as "destructive devices" under the NFA

Comment: In Greek, there are four words that can all be translated as "love": storge, eros, philia, and agape.

Storge -- στοργή -- is the love a parent has for a child.

Eros -- ἔρως -- is a sexual love.

Philia -- φιλία -- is a dispassionate love. In Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics, philia is used to mean loyalty to friends, family, and community, and would be the term used in a phrase such as "I love baseball".

Agape -- ἀγάπη -- is the sort of love that Jesus was talking about when he said "No one has greater love than this, to lay down one's life for one'’s friends." -- John 15:13. It is the love of God for humanity and of humanity for God. Paul uses it in 1 Corinthians 13, where it is translated "charity".

Comment: If properly designed and implemented, value capture can promote more affordable development near transit.  Some communities have achieved this by transforming their property tax into a value capture fee.  This is accomplished by reducing the tax rate applied to privately-created building values while increasing the tax rate applied to publicly-created land values.  The lower rate on buildings makes them cheaper to construct, improve and maintain.  This is good for residents and for businesses.  Surprisingly, the higher rate on land helps keep land prices more affordable by reducing the profit from land speculation and thereby reducing the speculative demand for land.  

For more info, see "Funding Infrastructure to Rebuild Equitable Green Prosperity" at http://revitalizationnews.com/article/funding-infrastructure-for-sustainable-equitable-revitalization/

Teachers cannot do miracles for students told school sucks.

Comment: Rich creditors?!?!  What "rich creditors"?  Greece defaulted on their debt back in 2012, their non-government creditors received pennies on the dollar.  Those creditors don't deserve pity but equally they don't deserve any scorn, they took their lumps and won't touch Greek debt with 10-foot pole.

The creditors now are government organizations, the EU, ECB and IMF who have lent Greece money taken from other countries taxpayers (including Canadians, we help pay the bills for the IMF).  Why?  All so that Greece could continue to stay on the Euro.

The solution is, and always has been, for Greece to abandon the Euro and reprint their own currency then devalue it until they reach a level of poverty that is sustainable given their productivity.  That isn't being "mean", it is being realistic for everyone involved, both creditors and borrowers.

Comment: The iconic reporters' scrum or feeding frenzy you describe is actually extremely rare. In Montana it was one reporter asking questions of someone who possesses information the public has a legitimate right to know. People who put themselves in the public eye, by running for office, for example, should expect to face reporters who will sometimes ask uncomfortable questions. Which is all to say that there is never an excuse for violence against journalists (or, you know, anyone who is not threatening you with actual harm) and there is simply no valid argument to normalize it.

You don't want press releases and news conferences. I've created and coordinated both. What you end up with is pre-digested, wordsmithed, and nuanced statements that give the impression of information with no real content. You really want reporters who ask hard questions. It's the only way we learn anything of value.

Comment: The proposal for a Constitutional Convention makes me very apprehensive. There are some anachronisms in our Constitution such as the provision of "Letters of marque and reprisal" and the Third Amendment but they also haven't gotten in the way of governance. Better to heal the divisiveness and work for consensus about interpreting our existing Constitution in a manner that benefits all Americans.

Comment: Speed is NOT the only factor that determines whether someone survives a crash or not.  It is the RATE of deceleration.  Motorcycle racers at Daytona have survived crashing at over 180 mph because their rate of deceleration after their crash is gradual.  In other words they do NOT hit anything solid like a retaining wall or other barrier, rather they slide in their leather suit to a gradual stop.  Some races are deemed much more dangerous than others such as the Isle of Man TT because they race on roads so close to building, walls, barrier, etc. They design SAFE race courses by making sure there is ample run-off with NO obstructions/barriers to allow that gradual rate of decleration.  It is simple PHYSICS, in a crash situation, whatever the speed, you do NOT want to have large fixed barriers or objects in the vicinity of a highway, road.  Yes they were speeding however if they rail columns & elevated curb was not there & they used a car with better crash protection, might have survived.

Comment: In 1852 Kennedy discovered Bellot Strait, which was a key link in the navigable Northwest Passage. Peel Sound was often blocked and Bellot Strait provided an alternate way to Franklin Strait.

Bellot Strait is east, though not directly east, of King William Island. With Franklin Strait (charted by McClintock in 1859), James Ross Strait, and Rae Strait, it's part of what I called "the crucial track east of King William Island." I used this shorthand because it was impossible to explain all the geographical details within my assigned word limit.

McGoogan doesn’t contest the point that Franklin might not have discovered Franklin Strait in 1846. If he didn't, then it was McClintock who found the "last link" when he travelled along the east side of Franklin Strait in 1859 -- five years after Rae found Rae Strait.

As McGoogan notes, I am not the only historian to disagree with him. I don't see how that fact casts any doubt on the validity of my comments.

Janice Cavell

Comment: The PM is assuredly not a one person show in this era of huge, complex, costly government that began in the 1930s.

So yes, that rarest of abilities - the ability to identify, inspire, integrate within a team, support and get the best out of senior executive talent - is critical to national leadership today.

But if the leader is to lead rather than being a token leading in the way a ship's figurehead is said to be leading the ship other executive abilities and talents are also required.   Otherwise the "leader" is really a sham and a fraud on the electorate.

In addition to interpersonal skills, a leader needs to be highly intelligent, capable of articulating to the people and to his team a vision and values that inspire them, able to set priorities, milestones and accountability for their achievement, and able to radiate confidence and courage in tough times.

So degrees are much less important than previous executive experience as a governor, minister, general, or private CEO.

Comment: Urban infrastructure involves massive initial investment.  It also requires significant maintenance as it approaches the end of its design life (e.g. Gardiner Expressway).  

Certainly, suburban commuters should reasonably be expected to chip in, but beyond the commuting orbit, there is no ROI for the federal or provincial taxpayer on transfers to support urban infrastructure.  For example, about one-third of Canadians have no meaningful access to public transit whatsoever.  

Urban property tax rates are a fraction of rural and suburban rates.  They need truing up to reflect where the value of urban infrastructure investment comes to rest.  The current incongruity is not invisible to foreigners buying property here.

Comment: To be clear, the Fed interest rate hike itself is not "good news" for the Canadian dollar. Increased oil prices are. To the extent the Fed's announcement was positive for the dollar, it is that the reading of the "tea leaves" in the Fed statement around the increase led traders to conclude they had over-sold the Canadian dollar because they now believe US interest rates will rise more slowly than they believed they would the day before. That is they are guessing that their previous guess on interests rates was a little off. The luckiest guesser will make the most money.

Canada is too often taken for granted in the U.S. generally and more specifically by the current administration.  There is no reason for us to get beat up at all in these negotiations if we stand firm and understand the pressures we can exert. Comment: We should take our cues from countries that have little corruption, and well functioning democracies - openness, transparency and accountability are good virtues, but they come into being through solid, practical systems. 

Let's take Sweden for example. Here, as in Sweden, there is a freedom of information act. Here if you request a document under the FOIA you will spend many weeks waiting for it, unless it's appealed, in which case it could take months and a not insignificant amount of money spent on lawyers to fight the appeal.
In Sweden, you walk into the local office of the department that issued the document and they have to - by law - produce it in less than an hour. Failure to do so leads to the automatic firing of the head of department (who suddenly has a LOT of incentive to ensure every branch office is up to scratch !)

That's how you do it - by making laws that not only establishes rights, but sets expectations on them - and punishments for leaders who fail to meet them.

Comment: It seems that Anchorage may have outgrown her present "leash-laws".
I realize that this particular situation falls into a grey area: a poorly mannered dog in his electric-fenced yard, scares a new neighbor with a small child. Chaos ensues.

Last year we had a bizarre experience in the same grey area.  My crew joined my SIL, niece and dogs for a walk.  The dogs were unleashed and under voice-control.  She and I had looped a pond by a school and were approaching the playground, where my kids & hubby were playing. Both dogs were ten feet in front of us.  A man at the playground stepped out and smacked one dog with a ski pole and began screaming at us about leash laws.  She recalled her dogs, who sat at her side while the man continued to brandish the pole and scream. My Popeye-esque husband hustled over and his presence caused the man to lower his voice and his pole. We promptly left.

The laws need clarification before someone gets hurt.

Good fences make good neighbors.

Comment: For what it's worth, the Russian word for swamp is болото but the stress is on the middle syllable. When the syllable before the stressed syllable has the vowel о, it is pronounced more or less like a "long a." (This is a little misleading, because many American speakers pronounce only two different sounds for the three vowels "long o", "long a" and "short a.") 

The unaccented penult after an accented antepenult is pronounced schwa. 

So, just for once, MSW is approximately right. He probably asked a Russian friend for the word for swamp and wrote down what he heard.

Comment: What has become the "downtown relief line" was first presented to me as a Toronto federal MP in about 1978.

The then plan was to run it south from Fairview Mall to the proposed Leslie barns and then west to the city centre on either Queen or King (where stations had already been roughed in on both the Yonge line and the Spadina - University line).

Then, the Davis government stopped funding subway infrastructure and started funding community recreation infrastructure. Despite the construction of a much shortened Sheppard line from Yonge to Fairview Mall, the short extension of the Yonge subway line north to Finch  and the nearly completed extension of the Spadina - University line to York University, Toronto has never recovered its vision (or the Province's vital support) in building its much needed subway infrastructure.

Mayor Tory is right to stress completing Toronto's subway infrastructure before expanding beyond Toronto's boundaries.

Comment: It is impossible for any thinking person to fail to notice Alaska's staggering alcohol problem; the question then becomes this: What, if anything can we do that will improve the numbers?

World-wide, there has been research and models that prove we can do better. Unwittingly, Alaskans gave harm reduction advocates a win with marijuana legalization.. Portugal legalized drug possession and shifted to the view of the medical nature of substance abuse problems.

As a people, we have yet to come to grips with even acknowledging that alcohol is really a problem. About 3 weeks ago, I was at a domestic violence fundraising dinner. Alcohol was served and middle school students ushered the event. Teachers were drinking in front of students and so on. Alcohol is the fuel that powers domestic violence. Go figure.

Comment: I think limiting citizenship to one generation is unrealistic and punitive.   We lost citizenship in 2004 after living here since 1946.  My father came to Canada originally as a Home Child from Scotland,   worked hard on farms for 15 years and only left to volunteer with the Royal Canadian Artillery throughout WWII.  He served as a Sergeant with the 14th Regiment,  Juno Beach and the Liberation, and was discharged back home to Ontario  in 1945.  My mother (War Bride), brother and I joined him in May, 1946,  told we were citizens and never left. . My brother is a veteran of the Canadian Navy and a police force.   We all worked, farmed and paid taxes yet none of that was good enough for the last government, who said we should never have had that citizenship.    At this point,  we are still without it..  Our children are all good Canadian citizens, born and lived here always, but entitled to British as they had a parent born there..
Canadians deserve a better, more secure Citizenship Act.

Comment: I went to see Led Zeppelin in London back in 2007 and i think they and the promoter did just about everything that could be done to thwart scalpers.

Everyone had to pick up their tix the day before/of the show and had to produce:
The email from the promoter giving the URL of the special Ticketmaster site set up for the show and the code that each buyer needed to get tix in the first place;
The credit card used to buy the tix (bad luck if your daddy bought them and didn't show up)
Government issued photo ID that match the name of the buyer/credit card owner; 
A copy of the statement for the card where the address matched the ID and the name matched too.

In the course of a good few hours lined up to pick up my tix, i watched maybe 30-40 fights break out at the pickup point when people realized that they weren't going to get to see the show and they were out maybe $3-4,000 a ticket that had just lined the pocket of the scalpers.

Intrusive and expensive, yes, but way effective.

Comment: Lets just pass a few citizen sponsored initiatives/amendments, and we can rectify this real fast:

1) The Legislature is legally bound to adhere to all citizen passed initiatives, as representatives of the people.
2) The Legislature's capital expenditures and discretionary budget will be approved by voters.
3) The Legislature will have their salaries and staff allowances set by voters. Legislators may spend their staff allowances as they see fit.
4) The Legislature will pass a budget in 90 days or be recalled to special session as an unfunded mandate. Failure to pass a budget by July 1st will automatically cause previous funding levels to be carried over until such time as a new budget is passed (automatic continuing resolution).

We stabilize things for state employees, our businesses and economy, and send a clear message to the Legislature they don't get to act like Congress.

Comment: Re rural electrification, I suspect you are well aware that the federal government had to facilitate this because it was initially not deemed sufficiently profitable by private for-profit electricity producers.  I also believe you are correct that the "progressive era" government "response", in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, was to regulate electricity producers or nationalize them to stop price gouging.  But it is less obvious nationalization was chosen in most cases--unless, of course, you are referring to rural electrification and the federal creation of non-profit entities such as the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA).  

But my impression is rural electrification was achieved by creation of many of the larger, and most of the smaller, non-profit customer-owned electric utility co-ops on the mainland, predecessors to the 14-year old Kauai Island Utility Cooperative, and possibly future co-ops or non-profit taxpayer-owned utilities on the Big island and in Maui County-cont

Comment: I actually think that's an honest question, but I think the better question is why the US shouldn't continue to extend its tradition of welcoming immigrants to this generation? We can build all the walls we want, on our lands and in our hearts, but the great majority of undocumented people have simply overstayed their visas, so we're not likely to stop most of them at the borders. That cities consider the people who have lived and worked within their boundaries to be friends rather than aliens, seems consistent with American values, no? 
As someone who went through a years-long and fairly expensive process to obtain residency, I empathize with those who say all immigrants should be required to do the same. But the reality is that we can't go back to a point in time when we have that choice. We have people living among us who have mixed their lives and fortunes with ours, and their presence challenges us to decide what our values are.

Comment: Last year I went fishing and set my net in the Alberni inlet. My dad stayed nearby until I had the net set. Dad left to set his net, when I realized I forgot to get the markers for my net. So I had to leave my net there and reach dad by boat. When I got back to the net, it was gone. DFO had pulled it out of the water and cut it in half. So instead of catching food fish, I was out $5,000.00 (just the sort of treatment that I expect from DFO, they could have waited 15 minutes, the time it took to get the markers).

Port Alberni sells the licences to the commercial fishermen and the seiners. Where does the money go -- schools, hospitals, etc. Tseshaht needs a Assisted Living Facility, and the like.

When I was young I remember catching enough fish to last all year. Now with the commercial fishermen, the seiners and the sports fishermen have access to our resources we only have a few days a year that we fish (for conservation) we hardly get enough fish to last all year.

Comment: That's funny. I remember the winters of 71-72, 72-73, and 73-74 as high cycle years for hares. 71-72 was my senior year of high school in Cordova. We had great hare hunting there that year.  And as a member of the basketball team, we made some long road trips. We'd ferry to Valdez, then bus to wherever we were playing. I remember a couple trips over Thompson Pass where to amuse ourselves, we'd count the number of hares the bus ran over. (we'd also cheer the ones that made it up the bank and got away). One such trip the count was over 100 hares that the bus got. 

My first two winters after I graduated, I did a lot of hare hunting to add meat to the larder and the population was still quite high. Never tries snaring them. I always liked head shots with a .22. Never wasted any meat. Was easy to get 20 a day or more in those years. Besides the Cordova area, I also liked hunting up the Matanuska river between Sutton and Chickaloon and over towards Glenallen.

Comment: Animals with antlers grow new antlers each year.  While antlers are growing, they are covered with a vascular membrane called "velvet", which provides nourishment to the growing antler.  Once the antler has grown and hardened, the velvet is shed in late summer, which is what is happening in this photo.  The animal will then shed the entire antler in early winter (for male caribou) or early spring (for female caribou).  A new antler will then start growing in the spring.  All antlered animals including deer, moose, elk and caribou have this (although caribou/reindeer is the only species where females have antlers - the rest only males have them).  Antler growth and shedding is regulated by the natural cycling of sex hormones, so it isn't really anything more disturbing than a menstrual cycle.

Comment: I read your link the first time, it wasn't relevant to your point then either. Where does that link show us that revenue comes from academics, as you claimed? Where does it identify revenue sources at all (as my link did)? As I explained and cited, revenue comes from a lot of sources, primarily tuition, fees, and other sources that are collected per student. This revenue is then divided to different university departments, including both athletics and academics.

You seem stuck on the fact that NCAA football rarely "pays for itself:' i.e. doesn't bring in revenues that exceed expenses, and that in many cases student fees are used to make up the difference. Nobody really disputes this, but student fees are not, and never have been, dedicated solely to academics. Just because you don't value football doesn't mean people choosing universities can't value it. Also, most people understand that athletics don't have to be profitable in a vacuum to be beneficial for the university overall.

Comment: While I agree with what you say overall (minus the anthropomorphism), for the sake of accuracy it should also be pointed out that Unalaska Island now supports about six times the number of eagles it otherwise could due to the increase in their food supply provided by the fishing and fish-processing industry there now.  Therefore incidents of conflict between eagles and other species deemed a threat (such as ourselves) are more likely to occur.  I have a photo of an eagle from very close up--he'd lost an eye in an aerial battle with another eagle and was perched on the wheelhouse railing of a long-liner, unable to fly because of his loss of depth perception.  Probably didn't turn out well for him.

But I hold them in special esteem--no just because they're related to T. rex, but because they prey on domesticated cats.  "Nature fights back."

Comment: Great story Mr. Dunham. I was born and raised in Fairbanks and still live here. I have been to Whittier three times, the first time was March of 2000 just before the tolls were started. I was in Anchorage for the Alaska State high school Tournament. I just wanted to say that I had driven through the tunnel. I had a beer in the bar, talked to some locals and drove back out. It was snowing. The second time was October of 2010, my wife and I drove in, looked around and left, we were on our way to Homer. It was raining. The last time was August of 2015, my wife, son and daughter in law arrived by Alaska State Fast Ferry from Valdez. It was a beautiful bright clear day and the sun was  beating down on us. The activity at the landing area was hectic. We ate a fish and chips lunch at a little summertime restaurant and had a beer on the deck of another restaurant overlooking the harbor and did some shopping. Water was pouring off of the glaciers above the little town. Great fun!

Comment: yes, many small pockets of methane seep out of lakes around here, the anaerobic conditions in lake bottom mud and peat support the methanogenic bacteria that produce the gas. the problem is not methane being toxic per say, as it is having methane pouring out in great quantities from the sea floor. Comment: That's too bad. Parents do a disservice when they force specific foods on children, especially when they are otherwise eating well. My father was a big fan of pickled beets, and likewise tried to make me eat them. I found them disgusting, along with turnips, rutabagas, and parsnips. To this day I can't stomach them, although I wonder if, as an adult, I might have found them at least palatable if it were not for my childhood experience. I know that these root crops are healthy foods, but they aren't for me.

Our tastes change as we get older. I don't think that as a child I would have liked Brussels sprouts, but never tried them until I was an adult. We have served Brussels sprouts, cooked similarly to the above recipe, to friends who heretofore did not care for them, and they found them enjoyable. So, maybe worth a try for doubters. If not, just more for us!

Comment: This is about tribal membership and jurisdiction over members , not some larger notion of how much Native one might be and whether a tribe could reach out and take over jurisdiction of a non-enrolled child.
Under federal law tribes determine by explicit rules who may be enrolled in their tribe.
"... tribal nations use a variety of criteria in determining their membership. These tools may be used in combination as well. For example, many tribes who use descendancy may also use blood quantum defined in terms of either tribal blood or Indian blood.  Others will combine parental residency requirements with descendancy."
http://genetics.ncai.org/tribal-sovereignty-and-enrollment-determinations.cfm
This does all get sticky when a child is an enrolled member and a parent is not. Though there is some case law which addresses the rights of that parent  , much is still being duked out there.

Comment: You can break Alberta into three political regions, Calgary which is very fiscally conservative, rural Alberta which is socially and fiscally conservative, and Edmonton which is socially and fiscally more progressive.

Unless something drastic changes before the next election, I would expect the new conservative party to capture more than 50% of the vote in over 50% of the ridings simply based on their popularity in Calgary and Rural Alberta. If the party tilts too socially conservative they may lose a handful of ridings in Calgary but not enough to lose the election. If they piss off government union workers that may lead to the NDP being more popular in Edmonton but will not impact the Conservative's election chances.

Comment: I think there's gotta be a middle ground here. The traffic problem on the North Shore won't be solved by taking away the food trucks (because honestly, there's no place like the North Shore), and the littering problem is not caused by all tourists. I've seen lots of locals/businesses/developers disrespect the land much worse. The best thing about the food trucks is that it gives the area some soul and personality. It's not the typical fast food joint, it's not a big corporate gig, and it's far from town. It's small business, it's artistic, gives people a chance to live their dreams and also an job/income creator. Find a way to provide proper amenities, permits and parking, as I'd like to see more soul and less ego drive the economy. Also, make recycling a priority at all beach parks with composting bins included with information board. You can't stop the people from coming, especially since the state advertises and relies so heavily on tourism.

Comment: The target inflation indicator of the Bank of England, the UK HICP, aka the CPI, is dysfunctional, not incorporating owner-occupied housing costs in its measure, or more particularly housing prices. Even Carney recognizes excluding OOH costs as a defect of the UK CPI, although since David “Get Out of” Dodge was his mentor, he doesn’t see at all that excluding housing prices is a defect. The best monthly UK inflation indicator now available is the RPI excluding mortgage interest and council tax; its inflation rate was 3.3% in September, down from 3.4% in August, and it has been above or at the 3% upper bound since April. So the idea that the UK has just hit 3% inflation and it is a one-month blip, as suggested by Reuters, is simply delusional.

Comment: I was referring to things like physics and math classes I have had, observed, or have taught in public schools. I have met people who have had better classes but these were not in standard public schools.
Educational structure covers a lot of things.  One example is when students are passed on based on their ability to pass tests and do work using a particular learning style.  This helps some students but many are left behind. This structure was prevalent in earlier education in this country and in many foreign educational systems.
Another structural element is the use of a master teacher for certain areas with multiple other teachers who may not be certified under the direction of the master teacher. Such a plan can allow more flexibility is student placement rather than the age based grade level classroom with a teacher for that room.

Comment: In the 70's, I remember a newly constructed home (one of several) off of Checkmate Dr. that was left suspended over a pit that opened up beneath it.  Blamed on melting Ice Lenses buried in the glacial soil deposits.  Same thing happened with an ATCO housing module I bunked in while working in Prudhoe Bay when the frozen tundra beneath it thawed and collapsed into a pool of meltwater.  We have sections of highway (Chena Hot Springs Road out of Fairbanks, for example) where it has been necessary to borrow pipeline technology and construct devices to remove warmth from the soil beneath the roadway.  Climate change is getting a bit more difficult to keep up with, these days.  May the lessons from the past lead to solutions for the future.  We're gonna need that!

Comment: I found it odd that the resident who was quoted as saying he didn't know the building didn't have fire sprinklers. He couldn't have looked at the ceiling or walls and determined this for himself? In my experience fire sprinklers are pretty easy to spot.

If there was no system warning residents and if state/local law doesn't require older high-rises to have sprinklers and similar warning systems, then the law should have been changed decades ago. Now at least three people have lost their lives, it didn't need to happen, and I doubt if legislative/regulatory priorities will ever be amended to try to prevent another tragedy.

Comment: I'm surprised that $10 million settles the claims of 300+ claimants. The implication is that a majority did not suffer career debilitating effects - which is reassuring. 

My suspicion is that the offenders to a large degree were older or now retired members of the force. I know a few young new RCMP officers and I think they grew up under different social and cultural norms. Left to their own devices, I think they would behave properly. My worry however is that, given the intense hierarchal nature of the organization, they may be under some subtle, even subliminal, pressure to join the old boys club - and not just as it relates to the treatment of women. 

When you have a work culture given not only to sexual harassment but to the heavy handedness typified by the Dziekanski tragedy, you need a very powerful counter-force to break that mold. There a few forces worldwide that have enjoyed the reputation and respect afforded the RCMP. It is a tradition worth reclaiming and preserving.

Comment: From a resume standpoint, I am always an advocate of honesty.  What you put on your resume and how you represent your experience is a reflection of you and your personal ethics.  To be caught in a misrepresentation would take you off the table immediately for me.  I never see anything wrong with owning up to a wrong choice.  I am more concerned about what you have learned.  

In terms of dealing with the company, again I recommend that you  take  the high road and do not burn bridges.  When you resign, provide fair notice and explain that the position was not what you thought it was going to be.  I would not recommend referring to misrepresentation.  If you gauge in this conversation that they would be willing to provide a reference letter regarding what you have accomplished, then certainly raise the question.

Leaving on a professional note, regardless of the perceived situation, is always important as you never know when you may encounter those people again in your career.

Comment: This utopic concept, "Case For Stewardship Logging" is out of touch with the reality of logging in Western Oregon... dominated by the landscape-scale clearcut, burn, spray and replant norm. 

Often maligned Federal forest management and logging is not the problem. 
The problem is industrial logging, accounting for 80% of  Oregon's annual timber harvest; harvest rates increasing with shifts of large forest ownerships to REITs; and the financial incentives to cut, replant, and cut again in less than 40 years.

Protecting ecological integrity and the public's entwined resources within private forests, like water and wildlife, from rampant industrial forest liquidation will realistically require more restrictive forest practice rules and penalizing taxation.

Achieving this will require end runs, like voter initiatives, around Oregon's corporately controlled legislature.

I say this have witnessed 50 years of unchallenged forest liquidation in the Pacific West as a forest professional.

Comment: It is with great dismay that our Canadian healthcare system does not cover the costs of dental care. The oral cavity is truly the gateway to the body. Infections of the gums (periodontitis)  leads to localized inflammation and bone loss but periodontitis is not a localized disease. Microbial products, and agents of inflammation travel beyond the tooth's gum tissues and travel to a variety of sites within the body. This can lead to low weight preterm babies, cardiac disease, bone loss, diabetes, and dementia. Surely the costs to the medical system for admissions to hospitals and treatments clearly out-price the costs for routine dental care.
Additionally, a poor dentition causes pain, malnutrition due to a decreased ability to chew healthy foods.  I have always been critical of our health system where hip replacements are free, but dental cripples are allowed to suffer . As a practicing dentist, it is about time that dentistry be included into the national framework of medicare.

Comment: Walt there are many ways to identify a military person driving the Alcan. Military members tend to have very squared away hair cuts; the short, close cut back of their heads for example. Many travel in partial uniforms. Many are not driving vehicles registered in Alaska. Many have some insignia showing their rank or unit showing in the windows of their vehicles. They tend to be in say the 23 to 45 years old age range. At most of the places you stop you'll hear them talking about where they are being transfer to.  

I'd say the best indicator would be to take a survey of the U-Haul locations.  That might result in a closer to reality count or military and not military travelers. OR ask real-estate brokers about available properties off base. 

Lots of the military go by ferry to or from  Belingham, WA. rather than having to cross into Canada with a firearm.  The past two summers the South and North bound ferries out of Whittier were all booked sold from late may to late August.

Comment: I like these "questions for reflection" and growth from Fr Francis Fernandez, from In Conversation with God:

"- What is the true motivation of my actions? 
- What is my heart really set upon?
- Have I really tried to be detached from earthly goods, or on the contrary, do I suffer and complain when I am short of something?
- How quick am I to react against the slightest incitement to self-seeking and ease, promoted very often by the advertisements of the consumer society? 
-Am I sparing in my personal needs, do I put curbs on my extravagance, do I avoid frivolous and unnecessary purchases?
- Do I cheerfully accept whatever inconveniences me and the lack of means at my disposal? 
- Am I generous in giving alms to those who are in much worse circumstances? 
- Do I contribute to the support of good causes, depriving myself of things I would like to have...?

Only in this way will we live with the joy and freedom necessary if we are to be disciples of our Lord in the midst of the world."

Comment: Re: " Those guns are illegal by the NFA of the 30's that banned these type of "readily convertible" weapons"

No - the NFA of 1934 said you could own one if you paid a $200 tax, which is still true today. The law was changed in 1986 to ban any new ones from coming on the market but the old ones were grandfathered. You can still buy one today under the NFA (if you can find a seller) but because the supply is limited they sell for thousands of dollars. According to the BATF there are currently 175,977 fully automatic legal machine guns in civilian hands and the only legal one I can find that was used in a crime since 1934 was by a police officer that killed an informant and it wasn't clear if the firearm was his or his department's.
