Comment: I'm ambivalent about zoos. Using wild critters as entertainment.
Educational value? Beyond "this is what a tiger looks like"? Hardly.
I suppose a reasonably landscaped acre or two beats a cage, but it is still a small enclosure for wild predators that roam tens of square miles in their natural habitat.
Hiding meat around the compound at feeding time may relieve boredom, but how about "Jurassic Park" style? Release a live goat or sheep, and call out "Here kitty!" THAT would be educational about lions and tigers in the wild!
Captive breeding babies to be released in the wild? That's more about making zoos (and their donors) feel good. The mammals that really attract the public's attention are all social animals. Taking a juvenile tiger or elephant or [ ] and releasing it to a wild herd I doubt works very well. It might work for endangered reptiles.
But, in the near future for many species, we have soon have either individual animals in zoos or watching them on Internet videos, so ...

Comment: On a related note,  our Ground Based Mid-Course Missile Defense System (GMD) is oriented towards incoming ballistic missiles launched from North Korea on a northeastern great circle trajectory.  That's why the Ground Based Interceptors are in silos in Alaska and California.  The North Koreans have demonstrated the ability to launch to the south,  with their KMS-4 satellite launched to the south, and approaching the US from the Southeast on each orbit.  To engage a similarly launched warhead,  the US would have to fire the interceptor from Alaska or California,  adding thousands of miles of unnecessary flight time to the intercept.  The US needs to build an Upgraded Early Warning Radar at the Pave Paws site at Eglin AFB Florida,  and a GBI silo field at either Ft Stewart or Ft Benning GA.    A UEWR at Diego Garcia watching Iran and another in Northern Australia would provide early tracking data post launch and before transit over the Antarctic.

Comment: Building 2400 sq ft (with the extra consumption a second structure entails) to "replace" 2700 of already existing/ functioning housing is wasteful. It most certainly isn't "green". There are three such "green" tech homes near us; the average build cost was close to 600/sq ft. This is "green" only in a monetary sense to the architect and builder. With energy costs at ridiculously low rates, and slated to continue so because of global energy discoveries, spending vast quantities on these innovations is irresponsible. The batteries, electronic equipment, plastics, and high-tech pieces are toxic to source and produce. Further, inserting a cottage next to your neighbors' backyards is invasive: gardens should be quiet, peaceful places--- and many such have become businesses, i.e. Airbnb. How many neighbors will enjoy having a motel next to them?
Lastly, a wise architect once said that the greenest home is a beautiful one: it will endure.
A garish, ultra-expensive craftsman? A folly, at best.

Comment: This article seemed didn't explain the claim that students "had" to take remedial courses.  Who made them?  Why?

The study suggests there is a direct relationship between high school performance and college performance, which there isn't.  The last I heard was that a high school diploma meant that a student did acceptable work in the high school curriculum, not that a high school diploma guaranteed a performance at any particular college.

Our top state education official doesn't seem to understand this.  He says, "when students receive a high school diploma 'it should mean...that you're ready for a job or you're ready to go to college and take college-level classes and for far too many of our students it doesn't mean that."  That's definitely not what a high school diploma is.  If he wants those outcomes, then provide more instruction and funding geared to those outcomes.  I've never heard of any high school required subject in "job readiness" or "college readiness."

Comment: Another thing that is not being looked at here--at least not enough--is the possibility of infection by Toxoplasma gondii oocysts.  The oocysts survive and remain infectious for up to 4.5 years--even in sea water.  They're contaminating nearshore marine habitat.  Filter-feeding fish like Pacific sardines and anchovies are taking them up and the oocysts are embedding in their tissues.  So are filter-feeding bivalves (enjoy those raw oysters, folks!).  The fish may be spreading them into the open ocean.  And the parasite is being ingested by marine mammals and killing them by the thousands from--at least--British Columbia to New Zealand and beyond.  They're definitely already in the Alaskan terrestrial environment--a pregnant woman and her unborn child were infected after she ate a moose which had ingested T. gondii oocysts two years ago.  If they're on land, runoff will carry them to the sea.

Comment: Statistical metrics are difficult and critical.   Without date, decision making become little more than guesswork.   

 Metrics can be distorted by intent or by human error. That isn't a reason to discontinue to data analysis, it just mean you need to have skilled trustworthy managers, not political appointee's in charge.   

No corporation would arbitrary cut 20% of their accounting department.  You can't know your performance without a measurement.    National data that directs federal funding must be accurate.    

My concern is that those that don't have the interest, or the ability to collect and analyze data will simply call it 'fake data' when they don't like what the facts are saying.    Those who deny the facts will try to discredit the source, most likely accusing those groups of trying to find ways to collect public tax's.    

Absolutely, we should take a fresh look at old processes, but we should expect proof that they don't serve a useful purpose.

Comment: ... an unacceptable risk re. property damage?

I have written to MMA multiple times to alert them to specific sites and to ask why they are allowing the very sensible safety requirements of the PPS to be violated. Their responses were vague and indicated no concern about safety or anything else.

Meanwhile, Toronto has a dozen sites where vulnerable facilities (the PPS calls them "sensitive uses") lie next to transmission pipelines. These "uses" include geriatric facilities, schools, a major transit hub, a hotel and several high-rises. The distance between the pipeline marker and the wall of the facility ranges from 10 feet to about 40 metres.

Anyone who is familiar with the literature regarding pipeline releases of flammable fuels knows the suddenness and extreme risks that are presented by such events. Pressures in these pipelines are extreme, usually between 500 psi and 1440 psi, resulting in a geyser effect: fuel is sprayed into the air creating a highly flammable aerosol.

Comment: A widely shared bit of text on the Internet says that "Lincoln was fervently making plans to send all freed slaves to the jungles of Central America once the (Civil War) was over. … The only thing that kept this from happening was his assassination."

This is incorrect on many levels. Even when he was arguing for voluntary colonization during his first two years as president, Lincoln did not envision forced deportations of ex-slaves. Moreover, historians agree that the idea of large-scale, voluntary colonization was effectively dead by the time the Emancipation Proclamation was issued on Jan. 1, 1863 -- more than two years before Lincoln’s assassination. We rate the claim False.

http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2015/jun/26/blog-posting/did-abraham-lincoln-plan-send-ex-slaves-central-am/

Comment: Jonathan Light's resignation from the Springfield Board is a loss, but his new job with the Springfield district is a gain. Very few school boards in the U.S. have had the guts and the vision to say, "Enough of this madness".  From all I have heard, the Board has received no negative comments from Springfield parents.

These tests and the accompanying irrational beliefs  --   that the only thing that matters in school are the tested subjects (reading, writing and arithmetic) and that all students should go to a four-year college --  have crowded out so many subjects of value to students and to society.  The real world is made up of people - students - who are great at working with their minds and hands (skilled labor, the arts, etc. etc.) and people who are good at traditional academics.  

Thanks for your service, Jonathan.

Comment: We manage parks for people across the entire state. That's what I mean by taking a system-level view. We're not cutting trees down -- they have fallen in storms on their own, and that could continue -- but what we're doing is facing facts. Some parks have a lifecycle. They're born, serve, and then decline, and eventually end. It doesn't happen often, and it's affected by many external factors: character of the property, level of use, funding, and other things. All parks have costs, even if they aren't functioning as originally intended, and as hard as it can be to admit, we do have to decide whether we keep a piece of property for an eternity even if it's not really working very well anymore. In this case, we decided to try and sell rather than allow it to continue to decline (yes, "try" ... this may not work). As far as people who need a piece of pavement to park for a short time, Junction City is 5 miles south, Monroe is 3.5 miles north, and Corvallis is another 16 miles past that.

Comment: Three things come to mind here.  The first:

1)  There seems to be a view of the Eucharist proposed by some (including perhaps the present pope) that verges on magical thinking:  the notion that the Eucharist is some sort of spiritual vitamin that perks us up--the corollary being that if you don't receive Communion you run the risk of becoming spiritually malnourished.  So it follows that it can only be 'merciful' to open Communion up to the divorced-and-remarried, and indeed (following the logic further) to all comers.

While we can't expect to hammer out a complete Eucharistic theology in a combox, I'd suggest this view is in many ways deficient.  An alternative is one in which the Eucharist encourages us to repent of our sins and reform our lives.  Instead of insisting that the Eucharist be supplied to us, we should move towards personal holiness and thus be bring ourselves closer to the sacrament.

Comment: The problem is Wind and Solar are not reducing C02 and our government will not admit this costly failure. Ontario’s professional Engineers, those tasked with generation, transmission and billing, have reported the problem. our government continues to build more wind and solar.

Reference: “Ontario’s Electricity Dilemma – Achieving Low Emissions at Reasonable Electricity Rates”. Ontario Society of Professional Engineers (OSPE). April 2015.
(Archived at: http://c.ymcdn.com/sites/www.ospe.on.ca/resource/resmgr/DOC_advocacy/2015_Presentation_Elec_Dilem.pdf)

Page 15 of 23. “Why Will Emissions Double as We Add Wind and Solar Plants ?”

– Wind and Solar require flexible backup generation.

– Nuclear is too inflexible to backup renewables without expensive engineering changes to the reactors.

– Flexible electric storage is too expensive at the moment.  Consequently natural gas provides the backup for wind and solar in North America.

Comment: In its simplest form, that is true. The Oil and Gas commission have similar controls on operations that are intended to protect from harm. But you cannot just prevent mining and extraction because you don't like it. The right to natural resource extraction is written into the founding documents of the state.

Comment: The facts: the area within which humans will be vaporized in a nuclear detonation is a small fraction of the area within which they will be at danger. For many people, taking cover would be a prudent and effective response.

Within a limited radius of the detonation, humans may be vaporized. Outside this radius, there would be an extreme heat wave that would burn people to death. Outside that radius would be a vast area that would be affected by a blast wave not very different from the blast wave of a conventional explosive. Taking cover to avoid falling debris is your best strategy in a blast wave. The subsequent effects of nuclear radiation are harder to predict. They depend on topology, weather, public health, etc.   

Crawling under the heaviest object in sight may not save your life. But if everybody does it, it will save a lot of lives. Disparaging it earns liberal applause, but only at the expense of irresponsibly teaching falsehoods about efficacious civil defense measures.

Comment: You're right, Sans Flangi.  Did you know that some states, such as Tennessee have what's called Community Supervision for Life? That law requires certain sexual offenders who have served ALL their time to be placed on parole-type supervision for at least 15 calendar years minimum.  At the end of the 15 years the offender can petition the sentencing court to be released from supervision, but the court is under no duty to grant the petition.  If denied, an offender has to wait 3 years before renewing the petition.  Couldn't you see a judge repeatedly denying a petition until the offender dies of old age? My point is this:  in some states the offender is never even given the chance to show they are willing and determined to stay offense-free without all the intensive supervision and containment strategies.  That means their constitutional rights are diminished for life.  Parolees have lower rights than others.

Comment: Actually HRS 291C-33 states 
(1) Walk or Walking Person. Pedestrians facing such signal may proceed across the roadway in the direction of the signal and shall be given the right-of-way by the drivers of all vehicles.

(2) Don't Walk or Upraised Palm. No pedestrian shall start to cross the roadway in the direction of such signal, whether flashing or steady, but any pedestrian who has partially completed the pedestrian's crossing on the Walk or Walking Person signal shall complete the crossing to a sidewalk or safety island while the Don't Walk or Upraised Palm signal is showing.

This means you can't enter the crosswalk after the hand starts flashing, you can only enter the crosswalk when the Walk is illuminated.  If in the cross walk you continue across.  This is to give vehicles making turns and opportunity to make a turn with the light.  Lets not make this hard people!

Comment: ZLB, is a rules based low beta.  It contains the regular bank, insurance, reit, pipeline and utility of the dividend stocks, but seems to keep out the oil and gas sector which has been a disaster for the past 5 years.  It seems to be nicely diversified, less weighting in financials, material and energy and more in consumer, utility, real estate.

While not a true dividend ETF, per say as it does include stocks with lower dividends which provides some nice gains such as WCN, CSU, ATD.B, DOL

Five year return is 15.64 to end of Feb

This could be the solid core of a diversified portfolio.  I would add in about 30-50% US in healthcare, consumer, tech and industrial.  Hedge if you need consistency in currency, but the hedge costs and in the long run the currency seems to balance out.

ETF's are especially helpful in smaller accounts, such as TFSA or those just starting to invest.  It makes it easy to get good diversification without lots of small holdings

Comment: I'm sorry, but you are simply wrong in your dismissal of the legitimate connection between money and speech. What's worse is you don't appear to recognize the root problem itself: Too much power vested in government which attracts those who wish to control it. I agree that the US government (and others) has been on a downward spiral away from liberty (democracy not being the same thing) for decades. At least a hundred years. But the fundamental problem is not the common sense understanding that money is a lubricant for speech and therefore ought not be limited but, rather, the number and scope of things over which the state get, has and maintains power and control needs to be strictly reduced and limited.

Comment: Just as an aside, being strong in technology or science (or any other area) doesn't imply that someone is, in general,  smarter or more capable than people who are not. Everyone has their own strengths and weaknesses.

Yes, being calmer and less defensive is critical to listening, which is critical to having productive conversations. It's why I adopt such a formal tone in my comments here: I try to be dispassionate so that I am hopefully more intellectually honest and less defensive. I'm not sure that it always works, but all we can do is try.

I, too, prefer to surround myself with people who are smarter and more capable than I am, both personally and professionally. Not too much "better," understand -- I do have an ego that can be bruised -- but enough to keep me on my toes!

Comment: Theology is not about angels dancing in pinheads; and theology has always been and remains the foundation of teaching. What the Church taught through the ages has changed, developed, evolved as much as and in tandem with theology. 

It is not true that the Trinity and Natures of Christ are found unambiguously in the NT (although they can be read back into the NT, as they have since the early Councils). Theology and teaching on Who God is, and Who Christ is, evolved in tandem. 

It is not true that our faith seen through the eyes of Aristotelian philosophy of the Thomists is my identical with our faith seen by the Fathers of the Church through the eyes of Platonism (actually, neo-Platonism). The Eucharist is superb example. Both Platonist eyes and Aristotelian eyes proclaim the "real" presence, but the meaning of REALITY assumed by those verbally identical proclamations hide a chasm of difference. 

I'm glad we concur on the Advocate; but her role does not mean simplistic stability.

Comment: 5. The Cannabis Act is designed to grant law enforcement extraordinary powers to suspend freedom of movement (guaranteed in the Charter) because drugged driving will put motorists/passengers at risk. The research on driving while high, indicates that cannabis isn't the problem, but rather combining cannabis and alcohol: "in a study of 1,882 motor vehicle deaths, the US Department of Transportation found an increased accident risk of 0.7 for cannabis use, 7.4 for alcohol use, and 8.4 for combined use. The simultaneous use of alcohol and cannabis produces significantly higher blood concentrations of Delta9-THC, as well as THC primary active metabolite, 11-hydroxy-THC, than cannabis use alone (from "any dose of alcohol combined with cannabis significantly increases levels of THC in blood" 2015. Journal of Clinical Chemistry). The take-away here: COMBINING cannabis & alcohol is a major problem, not necessarily cannabis alone.

Comment: Do you suppose the drafters of the Alaska State Constitution had this "paradigm shift"  in mind regarding exploitation of nonrenewable resources when they created the policies and authorities in Article 8 Sections 1 and 2? 

§ 1. Statement of Policy: It is the policy of the State to encourage the settlement of its land and the development of its resources by making them available for maximum use consistent with the public interest.

§ 2. General Authority: The legislature shall provide for the utilization, development, and conservation of all natural resources belonging to the State, including land and waters, for the maximum benefit of its people.

Comment: P. Morgan on Hillary's stinking hypocrisy- (and the NYT)

"Hillary Clinton, lest we forget, voted for the war which killed Captain Khan.


She was thus directly responsible for his death and the deaths of the thousands of other U.S. servicemen and women who died in Iraq.

Their blood, including Captain Khan’s, is on her hands.


And please don’t give me all this guff about her being the innocent victim of a pack of lies spun by President Bush and his neo-con mates Rumsfeld and Cheney.

She was a United States Senator, and it was her fundamental duty to ensure the merits of Bush’s case for war were legitimate.


Indeed, I can think of no greater duty for any Senator than to microscopically and forensically examine the case for committing any American troops to any war.

Hillary failed that duty, the Iraq War was an absolute shambles, hundreds of thousands of lives were lost, and the Middle East turned into a blazing tinder-box from which ISIS emerged emboldened to terrorise the world."
